messages: f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:25): Hi ... I have lots of ^@ characters in a textfile and want to get rid of them via a regex
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:25): however, I don't know what character this actually is
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:27): however, how do I get rid of it?
42857cbfdc1d5e00b2d7d10b0e4b7731 (21:29): meaning in the reg expression part type a control-v followed by control-2
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:31): hm, the first solution does not work (this is a german keyboard ... maybe that's a problem?) ... How do I enter <Char-0>, mgedmin?
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:33): c-v altgr-q (the german equivalent for @), won't work, either
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (21:33): but :%s/^@//g worked, where I entered ^@ by pressing Ctrl-V, u, 0, 0, 0, 0
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (21:33): ctrl-v, ctrl-j also worked for entering ^@
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (21:34): (the historic confusion of \n and \0 is annoying)
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:35): yay, that seemed to work
42857cbfdc1d5e00b2d7d10b0e4b7731 (21:41): DocTomoe: so did it work with c-v c-j and/or c-v 000?
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:45): c-v 0000 did the trick for me
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:46): crawling trough 50k+ lines and removing by hand would have been a hassle :)
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:51): mgedmin: its a csv-to-be, basically load-testing results from a webserver
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (21:51): where did the NULs come from?
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:51): the guy who write the testing suit is a windows hacker ... no idea what he coded.
ade2ba280c823b6462a992b994ecd802 (21:53): if every second character is a ^@, it looks like a utf-16 file to me
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:58): mgedmin: well, it was a ^@ at every line ending.
f8cb0ff4859107ad7d9ad6684cc28e0b (21:58): seems like it was a substitute for \n or something
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:13): when I'm using vim over ssh the cursor isn't visible at all times
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:14): how can I make it so that if I move around, I can always see it
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:14): is there a setting for this ?
29b7430fa96bbc1bd8e3bfe51a58d125 (22:20): floppyears: try setting a proper value for the TERM environment variable
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:23): dindinx: this happens in many computers not just this one :(
29b7430fa96bbc1bd8e3bfe51a58d125 (22:25): are you sure this variable is correctly set on these computers?
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:36): I have set them myself
f81553e317cf64c8229717aeb15a6c54 (22:36): I thought there was a setting
efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (22:40): What does au do again?
efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (22:42): i'm trying to organize and document my 800+ line ~/.vimrc
efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (22:42): I know but I was cleaning
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (22:43): then you were already in vim. even easier
8289f680d0802a7833201721665807ba (22:45): how can i append something to every line that begins with a certain string?

e7fd4b3e5ed49d0fef295f08cf92e495 (22:52): i'm doing an ascii drawing with vim.. i can't remember how to make it not care where the end of line is so that if i go down, it goes straight down instead of to the end of the line below
29b7430fa96bbc1bd8e3bfe51a58d125 (22:53): mauke: oh yes, you're right. imbezol: please ignore me.
e7fd4b3e5ed49d0fef295f08cf92e495 (22:54): hmm.. when i type :ve it takes me to the compile options
4c82176393abe7e4d2db0465a5f416d7 (22:57): Is there any way of determining what command will be run if you enter a prefix of it?
fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (22:58): well, you can press tab after the prefix
